summary: The Federal Court ordered Clorox Australia Pty Ltd to pay a total penalty of A$8.25 million for making false or misleading representations to consumers that certain GLAD kitchen and garbage bags were partly made of recycled ocean plastic, following court action by the ACCC.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/clorox-ordered-to-pay-825m-in-penalties-for-misleading-ocean-plastic-claims-about-certain-glad-products

summary: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia has paid a AU$7.5 million penalty after it sent more than 170 million emails that did not comply with Australia's spam laws.
source_url: https://www.acma.gov.au/sites/default/files/2024-10/Commonwealth%20Bank%20of%20Australia%20-%20Spam%20Investigation%20-%20Infringement%20Notice%20-%2015%20August%202024%20Redacted.pdf

summary: Charged ongoing contribution fees for financial advice to retail customers without disclosing, or properly disclosing those fees. It is estimated that over eight years, at least 25,000 customer accounts were charged at least A$10.6 million in fees that were not disclosed, or properly disclosed.
source_url: https://download.asic.gov.au/media/ajonl1ai/orders-westpac-inadequate-fee-disclosure.pdf

summary: The Full Court ordered Reckitt Benckiser to pay a revised penalty of $6 million (up from $1.7 million) for making misleading representations about its Nurofen Specific Pain products.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/full-federal-court-orders-6-million-penalty-for-nurofen-specific-pain-products

summary: Justice Mansfield ordered Baxter Healthcare Pty Ltd to pay a penalty of A$4.9 million for contraventions of sections 46 and 47 of the Trade Practices Act 1974. This followed a previous decision in 2008 by the Full Federal Court declaring that Baxter had breached the misuse of market power and the exclusive dealing provisions of the Act when it entered long term contracts with State health purchasing authorities.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/baxter-penalised-for-breach-of-trade-practices-act

summary: ING Bank (Australia) Limited, the promoter and investment manager of the ING Direct Superannuation Fund (Living Super), agreed to compensate around 24,500 members approximately A$5.38 million following ASIC concerns that statements made in its promotional material about the fees paid in connection with its Living Super product were potentially misleading.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2016-releases/16-296mr-ing-bank-compensates-living-super-customers-due-to-potentially-misleading-costs-and-fees-statements#!page=186&type=media%20releases

summary: The Federal Court imposed penalties totalling A$6 million on Honda Australia Pty Ltd, accepting Honda engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct, and made false or misleading representations to customers of former authorised Honda Australia dealerships Brighton Automotive Holdings Pty Ltd (Astoria), Tynan Motors Pty Ltd (Tynan) and Buick Holdings Pty Ltd (Burswood) by falsely stating that he dealerships would close or had closed and would no longer service Honda vehicles.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/honda-to-pay-6m-in-penalties-for-misleading-consumers-about-dealership-closures

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: ASICannounced a package of regulatory actions against Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) for loans approved through its former car finance business Esanda, including around $5 million in remediation.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2018-releases/18-013mr-asic-acts-against-anz-for-breaching-responsible-lending-laws-in-its-former-esanda-car-finance-business#!page=144&type=media%20releases

company_name: Bupa Aged Care Australia Pty Ltd
summary: The Federal Court ordered that Bupa Aged Care Australia Pty Ltd pay $6 million in penalties for making misleading representations and wrongly accepting payments for extra services not provided or only provided in part to residents at 20 aged care homes.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/court-orders-6m-in-penalties-against-bupa-and-compensation-for-consumers

summary: Citigroup Pty Limited refunded approximately A$5 million to around 230,000 customers, for failing to properly disclose that credit card international transaction fees apply to Australian dollar transactions where the merchant uses an entity based overseas to process its transactions.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2017-releases/17-093mr-citibank-refunds-5-million-in-credit-card-international-transaction-fees-as-asic-warns-consumers-about-international-transaction-fees#!page=170&type=media%20releases

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group agreed to refund around 25,000 customers approximately A$5 million after it failed to properly apply some fee reductions and fee waivers for customers who held an ANZ Access Basic account and who also held an ANZ consumer credit card or ANZ Everyday Visa Debit Card since 2007.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2016-releases/16-098mr-anz-to-refund-5-million-to-basic-account-holders-for-incorrect-late-payment-and-overlimit-fees#!page=200&type=media%20releases

summary: Origin Energy paid penalties totalling A$5 million after allegedly charging prohibited exit fees to more than 20,000 gas and electricity small business customers.
source_url: https://www.esc.vic.gov.au/media-centre/origin-energy-pays-5-million-penalties-allegedly-charging-exit-fees-thousands-customers

summary: Bankwest, a division of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, refunded approximately 10,800 customers more than A$4.9 million after it failed to link offset accounts to home loan accounts for some customers who had open accounts between 2007 and June 2016, resulting in customers being overcharged interest.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2017-releases/17-021mr-bankwest-refunds-almost-5-million-for-overcharging-interest-on-home-loans#!page=174&type=media%20releases

summary: Coles Group Limited agreed to pay Norco Co-operative Limited around $5.25 million for distribution to its dairy farmer members. The payments followed an ACCC investigation into whether Coles fully passed on to Norco a 10 cents per litre price rise it charged consumers for Coles branded fresh milk, as it claimed it would do in Coles' marketing materials.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/coles-to-pay-norco-dairy-farmers-around-525-million-following-accc-investigation

summary: The Federal Court of Australia ordered CBA to pay a A$5 million penalty after the Court found that CBA had breached the ASIC Act and Corporations Act for failures of their AgriAdvantage Plus Package (AA+ Package). The Court also ordered CBA to publish a Corrective Notice in the form determined by the Court.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2020-releases/20-129mr-cba-to-pay-5-million-over-the-agriadvantage-plus-package-royal-commission-case-study#!page=85&type=media%20releases

summary: Following an ASIC investigation, the Markets Disciplinary Panel (MDP) fined Macquarie Bank Limited A$4.995 million for failing to prevent suspicious orders being placed on the electricity futures market.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2024-releases/24-211mr-macquarie-bank-fined-a-record-4-995m-for-serious-market-gatekeeper-failure/?altTemplate=betanewsroom

summary: Four Jemena subsidiaries were ordered by the Federal Court to pay a penalty of A$5.5 million for breaches of the National Gas Rules related to the Day Ahead Auction (DAA).
source_url: https://www.aer.gov.au/news/articles/news-releases/jemena-penalised-55-million-breaching-national-gas-rules

company_name: Volkswagen Financial Services Australia Pty Limited
summary: ASIC settled its claim against Volkswagen Financial Services Australia Pty Limited (VWFSA), discontinuing its Federal Court proceeding and accepting a Court Enforceable Undertaking (CEU) from the car financier. The CEU will see VWFSA implement a consumer remediation program which will provide an estimated $4.7 million in redress to approximately 1,800 consumers.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2020-releases/20-239mr-asic-and-volkswagen-financial-services-australia-settle-federal-court-proceeding#!page=78&type=media%20releases

summary: The Federal Court in Melbourne ordered four foreign-based suppliers of marine hose to pay penalties exceeding $8.24 million for engaging in cartel conduct.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/8-million-plus-penalty-imposed-on-cartel-members

summary: The Federal Court ordered by consent that NSK Australia Pty Ltd pay total penalties of $3 million for its involvement in cartel conduct in relation to the price of bearings in Australia, in proceedings brought by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/3-million-penalty-for-bearings-cartel-conduct

summary: The Federal Court imposed a pecuniary penalty of $3.5 million against Prysmian Cavi E Sistemi S.R.L., an Italian corporation, for engaging in cartel conduct in relation to the supply of high voltage land cables in Australia.

summary: The Federal Court ordered Hewlett-Packard Australia to pay a $3 million civil pecuniary penalty for making false or misleading representations to customers and retailers regarding consumer guarantee rights.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/hp-to-pay-3-million-for-misleading-consumers-and-retailers

company_name: Societe Generale Securities Australia Pty Limited
summary: he company was fined A$3.88 million by the Market Disciplinary Panel (MDP), following an ASIC investigation, for failing to prevent suspicious orders from being placed on the electricity and wheat futures market.
source_url: https://www.asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2025-releases/25-189mr-societe-generale-securities-australia-fined-3-88-million-for-market-gatekeeper-failures/

summary: Citibank agreed to refund more than A$3.3 million to around 39,500 current and former customers for failing to refund customers when credit card accounts were closed with an outstanding credit balance.

company_name: Equifax Australia Information Services and Solutions Pty Ltd
summary: The Federal Court ordered that Equifax Australia Information Services and Solutions Pty Ltd pay penalties totalling $3.5 million for misleading and deceptive conduct and unconscionable conduct in relation to credit report services following joint submissions by Equifax and the ACCC.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/equifax-formerly-veda-to-pay-35-million-in-penalties

summary: Speed-E-Gas was fined for participating in a cartel covering liquid petroleum gas cylinders for forklifts.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/court-orders-penalties-of-83-million-for-sydney-forklift-gas-cartel

summary: The Federal Court in Melbourne ordered four foreign-based suppliers of marine hose to pay penalties exceeding $8.24 million for engaging in cartel conduct.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/8-million-plus-penalty-imposed-on-cartel-members

summary: Three subsidiaries of AGL Energy Limited (AGL) were ordered to pay a total of A$3.5 million in penalties by the Federal Court for breaches of the National Electricity Rules in relation to AGL's conduct during South Australia's state-wide blackout in 2016.
source_url: https://www.aer.gov.au/news/articles/news-releases/agl-pay-35-million-penalties-breaching-energy-rules

company_name: Sony Interactive Entertainment Network Europe Limited
summary: The Federal Court has ordered Sony Interactive Entertainment Network Europe Limited to pay $3.5 million in penalties for making false and misleading representations on its website and in dealings with Australian consumers about their Australian Consumer Law (ACL) rights.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/sony-to-pay-35-million-penalty-for-misrepresenting-playstation-gamers-rights

summary: The Federal Court of Australia ordered Westpac Banking Corporation to pay a pecuniary penalty of A$3.3 million for contravening s12CC of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 (Cth) (ASIC Act) through its involvement in setting Bank Bill Swap Rates in 2010.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2018-releases/18-341mr-court-orders-penalties-and-other-relief-against-westpac-for-bbsw-conduct#!page=122&type=media%20releases

summary: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has paid a record AU$3.55 million penalty after it sent more than 65 million emails that did not comply with Australia's spam laws.
source_url: https://www.acma.gov.au/sites/default/files/2023-06/Infringement%20notice%20-%20Commonwealth%20Bank%20of%20Australia.pdf

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: ASIC accepted an enforceable undertaking (EU) from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited (ANZ) after an investigation found that ANZ had failed to provide documented annual reviews to more than 10,000 Prime Access customers in the period from 2006 to 2013. Among other things, ANZ agreed to make a community benefit payment totalling A$3 million.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2018-releases/18-092mr-asic-accepts-enforceable-undertaking-from-anz-for-fees-for-no-service-conduct#!page=139&type=media%20releases

summary: Following action taken by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the Federal Court ordered Apple Pty Ltd to pay $2.25 million in civil pecuniary penalties for misleading advertising in relation to the promotion of its iPad with WiFi + 4G which has been found to have contravened the Australian Consumer Law.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/apple-pty-ltd-penalised-225-million-for-misleading-%E2%80%9Cipad-with-wifi-4g%E2%80%9D-claims

company_name: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited
summary: ASIC accepted enforceable undertakings (EUs) from Westpac Banking Corporation and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited in relation to the banks' wholesale foreign exchange (FX) businesses. ASIC was concerned that between 1 January 2008 and 30 June 2013, both banks failed to ensure that their systems and controls were adequate to address risks relating to instances of inappropriate conduct identified by ASIC. Among other things, each bank made a A$3 million community benefit payment.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2017-releases/17-065mr-asic-accepts-enforceable-undertakings-from-westpac-and-anz-to-address-inadequacies-within-their-wholesale-fx-businesses#!page=172&type=media%20releases

summary: ASIC accepted enforceable undertakings (EUs) from Westpac Banking Corporation and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited in relation to the banks' wholesale foreign exchange (FX) businesses. ASIC was concerned that between 1 January 2008 and 30 June 2013, both banks failed to ensure that their systems and controls were adequate to address risks relating to instances of inappropriate conduct identified by ASIC. Among other things, each bank made a A$3 million community benefit payment.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2017-releases/17-065mr-asic-accepts-enforceable-undertakings-from-westpac-and-anz-to-address-inadequacies-within-their-wholesale-fx-businesses#!page=172&type=media%20releases

summary: The Federal Court ordered Woolworths Limited to pay total penalties of $3.057 million for breaches of the Australian Consumer Law relating to safety issues with house brand products sold in Woolworths supermarkets, Big W and Masters stores.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/woolworths-misled-consumers-over-product-safety-hazards-%E2%80%93-ordered-to-pay-over-3-million-in-penalties

summary: AGL paid a shortfall penalty of A$3 million after failing to surrender enough certificates to offset its liability under the Victorian Energy Efficiency Target scheme.
source_url: https://www.esc.vic.gov.au/media-centre/agl-pays-3-million-shortfall-penalty

summary: Following an ASIC investigation, Citigroup agree to refund over A$3 million to 114 retail customers for losses arising out of structured product investments offered by Citigroup between 2013 and 2017. Citigroup will also write to over 1000 customers remaining in the products to provide them an opportunity to exit early without cost.

summary: The Federal Court ordered that AGL Energy Ltd subsidiaries, AGL Macquarie Pty Ltd and AGL Loy Yang Marketing Pty Ltd, operators of AGL's Bayswater and Loy Yang power stations, pay penalties totalling A$6 million for breaches of the National Electricity Rules.

summary: ASIC accepted enforceable undertakings (EUs) from each of the National Australia Bank Limited (NAB) and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) in relation to the banks' wholesale spot foreign exchange (FX) businesses. ASIC was concerned that between 1 January 2008 and 30 June 2013, both banks failed to ensure that their systems and controls were adequate to address risks relating to instances of inappropriate conduct identified by ASIC. Among other things, each bank agreed to make a A$2.5 million community benefit payment.

The penalties were imposed following the Court' findings of unconscionable conduct, undue harassment or coercion, false or misleading representations and breaches of the unsolicited consumer agreement provisions of the Australian Consumer Law (ACL).

company_name: GlaxoSmithKline Consumer Healthcare Australia Pty Ltd
summary: The Federal Court has ordered that the makers of pain relief product Voltaren Osteo Gel pay $4.5 million in penalties for breaches of the Australian Consumer Law. In May 2019 the Federal Court accepted admissions by Novartis Consumer Health Australasia Pty Ltd and GlaxoSmithKline Consumer Healthcare Australia Pty Ltd that they made false or misleading representations in the marketing of Voltaren Osteo Gel and Voltaren Emulgel pain relief products. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid half of the total.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/gsk-and-novartis-to-pay-45-million-in-penalties-over-voltaren-osteo-gel-claims

The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid half of the total.

summary: An ACMA investigation found Binance Australia sent over 5.7 million commercial emails that either made it difficult for consumers to opt-out by requiring them to log into an account or didn't contain a way to unsubscribe. The ACMA also found that Binance sent 25 emails without the consent of the recipients.
source_url: https://www.acma.gov.au/articles/2022-12/binance-australia-pays-2-million-penalty-spam-breaches

source_url: https://www.aer.gov.au/news/articles/news-releases/pacific-hydro-and-hornsdale-pay-over-16-million-penalties-breaching-energy-rules

summary: The Essential Services Commission accepted a court-enforceable undertaking with EnergyAustralia that will see it provide a customer remediation package of approximately A$1.2 million of credits and debt waivers, following alleged failures to inform struggling customers of their payment assistance entitlements.
source_url: https://www.esc.vic.gov.au/media-centre/energyaustralia-provide-more-1-million-bill-relief-after-breaching-consumer-protections

summary: Citibank refunded around 4,000 current and former customers more than A$1 million after misstating the bank's obligations around unauthorised transactions on customers accounts.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2017-releases/17-376mr-citibank-refunds-1-million-following-misleading-statements-made-to-customers-about-their-rights-under-the-epayments-code#!page=151&type=media%20releases

summary: Alinta Energy substantially improved its systems and waived more than A$1 million in energy debt owed by more than 400 of its affected customers, following an investigation by the Australian Energy Regulator (AER). The AER was concerned that during the period September 2019 to March 2020, Alinta Energy may have required vulnerable customers to make upfront payments or seek financial counselling, in circumstances where it should have offered customers access to payment plans or assistance to join Alinta's hardship program.
source_url: https://www.aer.gov.au/news/articles/news-releases/alinta-energy-improves-systems-and-waives-more-1-million-customer-debt-following-aer-investigation

summary: ASIC accepted an enforceable undertaking (EU) from ACE Insurance Limited following an investigation into Combined Insurance, a division of ACE Insurance. Under the EU, ACE Insurance was required to appoint an independent expert to review Combined's compliance systems, implement a remediation plan to compensate affected consumers and make a donation of A$1 million to financial counselling and financial literacy initiatives.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2016-releases/16-047mr-affected-consumers-to-be-compensated-as-asic-accepts-eu-from-ace-insurance#!page=203&type=media%20releases

company_name: Alinta Energy Retail Sales Pty Ltd
summary: Alinta Energy Retail Sales paid A$1,089,000 in penalties following a record 15 infringement notices issued by the Australian Energy Regulator (AER) after overcharging Centrepay customers and then allegedly failing to refund and inform them about overcharges within the required timeframe.
source_url: https://www.aer.gov.au/news/articles/news-releases/alinta-fined-1089-million-alleged-mishandling-centrepay-payments

summary: In response to ASIC's concerns, Westpac improved its lending practices when providing credit card limit increases to customers. Westpac also committed to a remediation program that included proactive customer refunds, and a contribution of A$1 million over four years to support financial counselling and literacy.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2016-releases/16-009mr-westpac-pays-1-million-following-asic-s-concerns-about-credit-card-limit-increase-practices#!page=205&type=media%20releases

source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/lactalis-penalised-for-dairy-code-breaches

summary: The Federal Court in Melbourne ordered four foreign-based suppliers of marine hose to pay penalties exceeding $8.24 million for engaging in cartel conduct.

summary: The company was fined for failing to identify suspicious trading conducted by one of its clients. enforcing_agency: National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority-NOPSEMA
summary: Petroleum operator PTTEP was fined A$510, 000 in the Northern Territory Magistrate's Court over the Montara wellhead platform blowout in the Timor Sea off Australia in 2009.
source_url: https://www.nopsema.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2021-04/The-Regulator-Issue-4-2012.pdf

summary: Following an ASIC investigation, the Markets Disciplinary Panel (MDP) fined J.P. Morgan Securities Australia A$775,000 for permitting suspicious client orders to be placed on the futures market, ASX 24.

summary: AGL Sales Pty Ltd paid a total of A$799,656 in penalties after allegedly failing to calculate its deemed best offer check in line with the prescribed formula for 22 customers over the period March to June 2022.
source_url: https://www.esc.vic.gov.au/media-centre/agl-pays-799656-penalties-over-allegedly-miscalculating-mandatory-customer-best-offer-energy-plan

summary: As part of a remediation program HSBC agreed to undergo following an ASIC investigation , the company reviewed 510 structured product advice files and determined that 82 files (16%) contained inappropriate advice. HSBC also tested and reviewed advice provided on other product types such as superannuation, insurance, annuities and other investments, and identified much lower instances of inappropriate advice having been provided in those areas. HSBC offered affected clients approximately A$690,000 in compensation across all product types.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2019-releases/19-036mr-asic-concludes-hsbc-s-enforceable-undertaking#!page=116&type=media%20releases

summary: The bank was fined for alleged failures to disclose, or accurately disclose, credit limit data in response to four separate requests made by different Consumer Data Right accredited providers on behalf of consumers.

summary: The Supreme Court of New South Wales found that Macquarie Investment Management Ltd (MIML) contravened the Corporations Act by failing to comply with its duties as a responsible entity of the van Eyk Blueprint International Shares Fund (VBI Fund). company_name: The Smith's Snackfood Company Pty Ltd
summary: The Smith's Snackfood Company Pty Ltd paid a penalty of $10,800 following the issue of infringement notices by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission for misleading healthy food representations.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/unilever-and-smiths-pay-penalties-for-misleading-healthy-food-representations

summary: Unilever Australia Limited paid a penalty of $10,800 following the issue of infringement notices by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission for misleading healthy food representations.
source_url: https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/unilever-and-smiths-pay-penalties-for-misleading-healthy-food-representations

summary: Australian unlisted public companies Johnson Matthey Holdings Limited and Johnson Matthey (Aust.) Limited were fined a total of A$10,000 for failing to lodge their annual financial reports.
source_url: https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/news-centre/find-a-media-release/2015-releases/15-015mr-johnson-matthey-companies-fined-for-failing-to-lodge-financial-reports#!page=232&type=media%20releases

enforcing_agency: Office of the Australian Information Commissioner
summary: The bank was fined for violating the privacy of a person who was both a customer and a former employee.
source_url: https://www6.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/viewdoc/au/cases/cth/AICmr/2016/80.html?context=1;query=%22commonwealth%20bank%22%20;mask_path=au/cases/cth/AICmr

summary: Two workers were exposed to toxic acid vapour.The company was also fined $10,000 for failing to notify WorkSafe after an employee was exposed to immediate risk when acid leaked from a sampling cabinet.
source_url: https://www.worksafe.vic.gov.au/news/2022-08/energy-company-fined-after-workers-exposed-acid

summary: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., a unit of tobacco manufacturer Reynolds American Inc., agreed to pay Canada C$325 million to settle government claims it aided cross-border cigarette smuggling following a move by Canada to increase tobacco taxes to discourage smoking.
source_url: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-04-13/r-j-reynolds-agrees-to-pay-canada-324-million-to-settle-smuggling-suit

summary: SNC-Lavalin Construction Inc.(SLCI) pleaded guilty today in the Court of Quebec to fraud contrary to s. 380(1) a) of the Criminal Code. In an Agreed Statement of Facts filed with the Court, the company admitted that between 2001 and 2011, $47,689,868 was directed to Saadi Gadhafi. In exchange for the payments, Saadi Gadhafi used his influence as the son of the Libyan Dictator Muammar Ghadafi to secure construction contracts for the benefit of SLCI, altering the competitive bidding process and causing a loss or a risk of loss to the Libyan people.
source_url: https://www.ppsc-sppc.gc.ca/eng/nws-nvs/2019/18_12_19.html

summary: JTI-Macdonald agreed to pay Canada C$150 million to settle government claims it aided cross-border cigarette smuggling following a move by Canada to increase tobacco taxes to discourage smoking.
source_url: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-04-13/r-j-reynolds-agrees-to-pay-canada-324-million-to-settle-smuggling-suit

summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) approved a no-contest settlement agreement with CI Investments Inc. in relation to a matter that CII self-reported to the OSC and that resulted in investors buying and selling units at an understated value. The settlement followed allegations by OSC Staff that CII's system of controls and supervision, and its monitoring and oversight of an outsourced service provider, were not sufficient to address the unique cash collateral feature of certain funds and to ensure that interest earned in related accounts was recorded and included in the net asset value. While having neither admitted nor denied the accuracy of the facts and conclusions of OSC Staff, CII agreed to the settlement and intended to compensate harmed investors a total of approximately C$156.1 million. In addition, CII made a payment of C$8 million to advance the OSC' mandate of protecting investors, plus a further payment of C$50,000 to be allocated toward the costs of the investigation.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-no-contest-settlement-ci-investments-inc-results-significant-funds-returned-investors

company_name: BMO Nesbitt Burns Inc. et al.
summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) approved a no-contest settlement agreement with BMO Nesbitt Burns Inc., BMO Private Investment Counsel Inc., BMO Investments Inc. and BMO InvestorLine Inc. (the BMO Registrants) in relation to a matter that the BMO Registrants discovered and self-reported to the OSC. This settlement followed allegations by OSC Staff that there were inadequacies in the BMO Registrants' systems of controls and supervision, which resulted in certain clients paying, directly or indirectly, excess fees that were not detected or corrected in a timely manner. OSC Staff did not allege, and said they found no evidence of dishonest conduct by the BMO Registrants. While having neither admitted nor denied the accuracy of the facts and conclusions of OSC Staff, the BMO Registrants agreed to the settlement, and intended to compensate clients a total of C$49,885,661, including opportunity costs on fees. In addition to the compensation to investors, the BMO Registrants made a payment of C$2,100,000 to advance the OSC's mandate of protecting investors, plus a further payment of C$90,000 to be allocated toward the costs of OSC Staff's investigation.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-approves-no-contest-settlement-agreement-bmo-nesbitt-burns-inc-bmo-private-investment-counsel

summary: Canada Bread Company, Limited was fined C$50 million by the Ontario Superior Court after pleading guilty for its role in a criminal price-fixing arrangement that raised the wholesale price of fresh commercial bread.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2023/06/canada-bread-sentenced-to-50-million-fine-after-pleading-guilty-to-fixing-wholesale-bread-prices.html

summary: Deloitte was sued for negligence for failing to detect fraud when auditing the books of Livent in the late 1990s. In 2014 it was ordered to pay C$84 million in damages. The case went up to the Supreme Court of Canada, which narrowed Deloitte's liability and reduced the damages to just over C$40 million.
source_url: https://decisions.scc-csc.ca/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/16920/index.do

summary: Following an investigation by the Competition Bureau, Yazaki Corporation pleaded guilty to bid-rigging under the Competition Act for its participation in an international cartel with other Japanese suppliers of motor vehicle components. The company was fined C$30 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222163956/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03560.html

summary: Katanga agreed to pay C$30 million to resolve a proceeding commenced by the OSC against Katanga and certain current and former officers and certain former Glencore nominees on the Katanga board. The settlement followed the investigation by the OSC into certain of Katanga's historic accounting practices, corporate governance and disclosure practices and related conduct by the individual respondents.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-panel-approves-settlement-katanga-mining-limited-former-and-current-directors-and-officers

company_name: RBC Dominion Securities Inc. et al.
summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) approved a no-contest settlement agreement with RBC Dominion Securities Inc., Royal Mutual Funds Inc., and RBC Philips, Hager & North Investment Counsel Inc. (the RBC Registrants) in relation to a matter that the RBC Registrants discovered and self-reported to the OSC. This settlement followed allegations by OSC Staff that there were inadequacies in the RBC Registrants' systems of controls and supervision, which resulted in certain clients paying, directly or indirectly, excess fees that were not detected or corrected in a timely manner. OSC Staff did not allege, and said they found no evidence of dishonest conduct by the RBC Registrants. While having neither admitted nor denied the accuracy of the facts and conclusions of OSC Staff, the RBC Registrants agreed to the settlement, and intended to compensate clients a total of C$21,802,231 including opportunity costs on fees. In addition to the compensation to investors, the RBC Registrants made a payment of C$925,000 to advance the OSC's mandate of protecting investors, plus a further payment of C$50,000 to be allocated toward the costs of OSC Staff's investigation.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-approves-no-contest-settlement-agreement-rbc-dominion-securities-inc-royal-mutual-funds-inc-and

summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) approved a no-contest settlement agreement with Scotia Capital Inc., Scotia Securities Inc. and HollisWealth Advisory Services Inc. (the Scotia Dealers) in relation to a matter that the Scotia Dealers discovered and self-reported to the OSC and that resulted in certain clients paying excess fees. This settlement followed allegations by OSC Staff that there were inadequacies in the Scotia Dealers' systems of controls and supervision, which resulted in certain clients paying excess fees that were not detected or corrected in a timely manner. OSC Staff do not allege, and they said they found no evidence of dishonest conduct by the Scotia Dealers. While having neither admitted nor denied the accuracy of the facts and conclusions of OSC Staff, the Scotia Dealers agreed to the settlement, and intended to compensate clients a total of C$19,997,821, including opportunity costs on fees. In addition, the Scotia Dealers made a payment of C$800,000 to advance the OSC's mandate of protecting investors, plus a further payment of C$50,000 to be allocated toward the costs of the investigation.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-approves-no-contest-settlement-agreement-scotia-capital-inc-scotia-securities-inc-and

summary: Volkswagen Group Canada Inc. and Audi Canada Inc. agreed to pay C$15 million to resolve allegations that they misled consumers by promoting vehicles sold or leased in Canada as having clean 2.0 liter diesel engines with reduced emissions that were cleaner than an equivalent gasoline engine.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2016/12/volkswagen-audi-pay-up-2-1-billion-consumers-15-million-penalty-environmental-marketing-claims.html

summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) today approved settlement agreements with Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) and The Toronto-Dominion Bank (TD) related to compliance failures in the banks' foreign exchange (FX) trading businesses. These failures allowed RBC and TD FX traders to share confidential customer information in chatrooms with FX traders at competitor firms.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/rbc-and-td-pay-more-24-million-foreign-exchange-compliance-failings

summary: The Competition Bureau announced that Bell Canada had agreed to stop making what the Bureau concluded were misleading representations about the prices offered for its services. Under the terms of a consent agreement filed with the Competition Tribunal, Bell was also required to pay an administrative monetary penalty of C$10 million.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200220175332/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03388.html

summary: Showa Corporation, a Japanese manufacturer and supplier of automobile components, pleaded guilty to one count of bid-rigging for participating in an international conspiracy and was fined C$13 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2016/04/japanese-auto-parts-company-fined-13-million-for-participating-in-a-bid-rigging-conspiracy.html

summary: Car parts manufacturer Mitsubishi Electric Corporation pleaded guilty to three counts of bid-rigging for participating in an international conspiracy and was fined C$13.4 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2017/04/mitsubishi_electrictopay134millionforriggingbidsforcarparts.html

summary: As a result of a Competition Bureau investigation into unwanted premium text messaging charges on customers' wireless phone bills, Bell Canada agreed to issue rebates to certain current and former customers totaling up to C$11.82 million and donate approximately $800,000 to public interest advocacy groups.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2016/05/bell-customers-to-receive-up-to-11-82-million-as-part-of-competition-bureau-agreement.html

summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) today approved settlement agreements with Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) and The Toronto-Dominion Bank (TD) related to compliance failures in the banks' foreign exchange (FX) trading businesses. These failures allowed RBC and TD FX traders to share confidential customer information in chatrooms with FX traders at competitor firms.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/rbc-and-td-pay-more-24-million-foreign-exchange-compliance-failings

summary: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) approved a settlement agreement reached between Staff and Ernst & Young LLP, the auditor of the financial statements of both Sino-Forest Corporation for its 2007 to 2010 fiscal years, and Zungui Haixi Corporation for its 2009 initial public offering and for its 2010 fiscal year. The settlement followed allegations by OSC Staff in 2012 and 2013 that Ernst & Young failed to conduct its audits of the financial statements of Sino-Forest and Zungui Haixi in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards, resulting in breaches of the Securities Act (Ontario) and that, in both cases, Ernst & Young's audit failures were contrary to the public interest.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-approves-settlement-agreement-ernst-and-young

summary: Facebook agreed to pay a C$9 million penalty after the Competition Bureau concluded that the company made false or misleading claims about the privacy of Canadians' personal information on Facebook and Messenger. Facebook was also to pay an additional $500,000 for the costs of the Bureau's investigation.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2020/05/facebook-to-pay-9-million-penalty-to-settle-competition-bureau-concerns-about-misleading-privacy-claims.html

enforcing_agency: Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada-FINTRAC
summary: The Toronto-Dominion Bank received an administrative monetary penalty of C$9,185,000 for five violations found during the course of a compliance examination conducted in 2023. This penalty was imposed for administrative violations committed by the bank under the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act and its associated Regulations, and not for criminal offences for money laundering or terrorist activity financing.
source_url: https://fintrac-canafe.canada.ca/pen/amps/pen-2024-05-02-eng

company_name: HSBC Investment Funds (Canada) Inc. and HSBC Private Wealth Services (Canada) Inc.
summary: In a settlement agreement with the British Columbia Securities Commission, HSBC Investment Funds (Canada) Inc. (HIFC) and HSBC Private Wealth Services (Canada) Inc. (HPWS) agreed they charged excess fees in some client accounts. The agreement noted that HIFC and HPWS cooperated fully with BCSC staff over the course of their review and were quick to implement a compensation plan. To address the failures, HIFC compensated 4,651 client accounts for a total of $7,076,651.35, and HPWS has compensated 10 client accounts for a total of $10,100.84. HIFC and HPWS have paid the BCSC $300,000 in respect of the settlement of this matter, and $20,000 in respect of costs.
source_url: https://www.bcsc.bc.ca/about/media-room/news-releases/2016/44-hsbc-entities-settle-with-bcsc-for-charging-clients-excess-fees

enforcing_agency: Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada-FINTRAC
summary: Royal Bank of Canada was fined C$7,475,000 for administrative violations under the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act and its associated Regulations, and not for criminal offences for money laundering or terrorist activity financing.
source_url: https://fintrac-canafe.canada.ca/pen/amps/pen-2023-12-05-eng

summary: The Competition Bureau announced that Korean Air Lines Co., Ltd. pleaded guilty to conspiracy under the Competition Act and was fined C$5.5 million for its participation in an air cargo price-fixing cartel between April 22, 2002 and February 14, 2006.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200220143918/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03482.html

summary: As part of an ongoing investigation by the Competition Bureau, Furukawa Electric Co., Ltd., a Japanese supplier of motor vehicle components, was fined C$5 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice for its participation in an international bid-rigging conspiracy.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222164156/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03555.html

summary: JTEKT Corporation, a Japanese automotive bearings manufacturer, pleaded guilty to two counts of bid-rigging under the Competition Act and was fined C$5 million by the Superior Court of Quebec in Gatineau for its participation in an international bid-rigging cartel.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222163700/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03583.html

summary: Toronto-Dominion Bank paid a C$6.5M penalty for the violation of the Cost of Borrowing (Banks) Regulations and of the Financial Consumer Protection Framework Regulations. Customers were not credited the credit card annual fee rebate because of inadequate procedures.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/financial-consumer-agency/services/industry/commissioner-decisions/summary-proceeding-2.html

enforcing_agency: Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada-FINTRAC
summary: Binance Holdings Limited, also operating as Binance Holdings (IE) Ltd., Binance.com, Binance Global, and Binance, was determined to be a foreign money services business. Binance Holdings Limited was imposed an administrative monetary penalty of C$6,002,000 on May 7, 2024, for committing 2 violations. The violations were found during the course of a compliance activity in 2023.
source_url: https://fintrac-canafe.canada.ca/pen/amps/pen-2024-05-09-eng

summary: Following an investigation by the Competition Bureau, Panasonic Corporation was fined C$4.7 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice for its participation in a bid-rigging conspiracy. Panasonic pleaded guilty to two counts of bid-rigging under the Competition Act.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222132451/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03669.html

summary: FCAC Staff alleged that the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CIBC) committed three violations of the Cost of Borrowing (Banks) Regulations between 2001 and 2020 for failing to accurately disclose security registration, search and renewal fees for fixed interest loans secured by movable property or investments, variable interest rate loans secured by movable property and investments, and investment secured personal lines of credit. The Commissioner found that CIBC had committed these violations as alleged and imposed a penalty for each violation for a total amount of $5.6 million.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/financial-consumer-agency/services/industry/commissioner-decisions/decision-143.html

summary: NSK Ltd., a Japanese bearings manufacturer, pleaded guilty to two counts of bid-rigging under the Competition Act and was fined C$4.5 million by the Superior Court of Quebec in Gatineau for its participation in an international bid-rigging cartel.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222132613/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03652.html

summary: TD Bank was fined for failing to adequately discharge mortgages-- the process a bank must go through to relinquish its right to seize a property once a mortgage has been paid off in full.
source_url: https://www.consumerprotectionbc.ca/recent-enforcement-actions-details/?cpbc_caseNumber=31435

summary: Toronto-Dominion Bank paid a C$5.5M penalty for a violation of the Bank Act. Some consumers that requested a change to their loan payment frequency had their amortization periods extended due to an error in the calculation of the principal and interest payment amounts. This error had financial implications which were not disclosed to customers.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/financial-consumer-agency/services/industry/commissioner-decisions.html

summary: Yamashita Rubber Co., Ltd., a Japanese supplier of motor vehicle components, pleaded guilty to two counts of bid-rigging under the Competition Act for its participation in an international bid-rigging conspiracy and was fined C$4.5 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice (East Region).
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200223001802/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03860.html

summary: The Competition Bureau announced that Hershey Canada Inc. pleaded guilty before the Ontario Superior Court of Justice in Toronto for its role in fixing the price of chocolate confectionery products in Canada contrary to the criminal conspiracy provision in the Competition Act. Hershey was fined C$4 million.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222131749/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03578.html

summary: Ticketmaster L.L.C., TNow Entertainment Group, Inc. and Ticketmaster Canada LP agreed to pay a C$4 million penalty and $500,000 for costs incurred by the Competition Bureau during its investigation into allegedly misleading pricing claims in online ticket sales.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2019/06/ticketmaster-to-pay-45-million-to-settle-misleading-pricing-case.html

summary: The Hudson's Bay Company agreed to pay a C$4 million penalty and $500,000 towards the Competition Bureau's costs to resolve a proceeding relating to Hudson's Bay's advertising and pricing practices for sleep sets in Canada.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2019/05/hudsons-bay-to-pay-45-million-to-settle-competition-bureau-investigation.html

company_name: Bloomberg Trading Facility Limited et al.
summary: The Financial Markets Administrative Tribunal rendered a decision approving a settlement agreement between the Autorite des marches financiers on the one hand and Bloomberg Trading Facility Limited, Bloomberg Trading Facility B.V. and Bloomberg SEF LLC on the other, thereby giving effect to an administrative monetary penalty in the amount of C$4,000,000 against BTFL, BV and BSEF. The agreement followed a review conducted by the AMF that revealed that BTFL and BV, two foreign corporations operating multilateral trading facilities for various financial products, including fixed income securities and swaps, had carried on business as an exchange in Quebec without being recognized as an exchange by the AMF. The review also revealed that BTFL and BV had filed applications for exemptions from recognition as an exchange with the AMF that contained inaccurate and incomplete information. BTFL and BV had also provided incomplete and inaccurate information regarding the scope of fixed income securities and derivatives trading conducted by Quebec participants on their MTFs.
source_url: https://lautorite.qc.ca/en/general-public/media-centre/news/fiche-dactualites/administrative-penalty-against-bloomberg-trading-facility-limited-bloomberg-trading-facility-bv-and-bloomberg-sef-llc

summary: Irving Oil Commercial GP was sentenced following guilty pleas in Saint John Provincial Court to 34 counts for offenses under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act. The Court ordered Irving Oil to pay a total of $400,320 in fines and $ 3,599,680 for the implementation of research programs in the field of safety standards under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act and its Regulations. In addition, Irving Oil was ordered to submit a corrective measures plan and follow-up with Transport Canada. Following the train derailment in Lac Megantic, Quebec on July 6, 2013, a joint investigation by Transport Canada and the RCMP revealed that Irving Oil did not comply with all applicable safety requirements by failing to determine the classification of dangerous goods for the crude oil it transported by train, and that the shipping documents on board the trains were erroneous. Irving Oil also failed to adequately train its employees in the transportation of dangerous goods, thereby committing an offence contrary to the Act.
source_url: https://www.ppsc-sppc.gc.ca/eng/nws-nvs/2017/26_10_17a.html

summary: Keurig Canada Inc. reached an agreement with the Competition Bureau to resolve concerns over false or misleading environmental claims made to consumers about the recyclability of its single-use beverage pods.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2022/01/keurig-canada-to-pay-3-million-penalty-to-settle-competition-bureaus-concerns-over-coffee-pod-recycling-claims.html

summary: A Panel of the Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) approved a settlement agreement in which BDO Canada LLP admitted that it failed to comply with generally accepted auditing standards in the audits of the 2014 and 2015 financial statements of two privately-offered investment funds. As part of the settlement, BDO has paid the Commission a C$3.5 million administrative penalty and C$500,000 towards the cost of OSC Staff's investigation.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/bdo-canada-pays-35-m-failing-comply-auditing-standards

summary: Engineering firm Genivar (which had become WSP Canada) was ordered to pay C$4 million for bid-rigging on municipal infrastructure contracts in Quebec.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2019/03/engineering-firm-to-pay-4-million-in-quebec-bid-rigging-settlement.html

summary: Syncrude Canada Ltd. was sentenced to pay an award of approximately $3 million. The award consists of: $300,000: This is the maximum fine available for an offence under the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994. This fine will be paid to the federal Environmental Damages Fund (EDF). $500,000: This is the maximum fine under Alberta's Environmental Protection Act. Half of the provincial fine will be directed towards the creation of a program for bird protection and monitoring and integrated with aboriginal training at Keyano College in Fort McMurray, Alberta. $2.2 million to be applied to the following environmental projects: $1.3 million to be held in trust by the University of Alberta for the Avian Protection Research Study; $900,000 to purchase lands in the Golden Ranches Conservation Area near Edmonton.
source_url: https://environmental-protection.canada.ca/offenders-registry/Home/Search

summary: Michaels of Canada, ULC agreed to pay a C$3.5 million administrative monetary penalty and to establish a corporate compliance program following a Competition Bureau investigation into price advertising for custom and select ready-made framing.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222130402/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03923.html

summary: The Autorite des marches financiers reached an agreement with Refinitiv Transaction Services Pte. Ltd. pursuant to which the latter would pay an administrative monetary penalty in the amount of C$3,500,000 for having carried on business as an exchange in Quebec without authorization.
source_url: https://lautorite.qc.ca/en/general-public/media-centre/news/fiche-dactualites/administrative-penalty-against-refinitiv-transaction-services-pte-ltd

summary: CIBC was fined over C$3 million for failing to adequately discharge mortgages-- the process a bank must go through to relinquish its right to seize a property once a mortgage has been paid off in full.
source_url: https://www.consumerprotectionbc.ca/recent-enforcement-actions-details/?cpbc_caseNumber=31452

company_name: Bloomberg Trading Facility Limited and Bloomberg Trading Facility B.V.
summary: A Panel of the Ontario Securities Commission approved a settlement agreement with Bloomberg Trading Facility Limited (BTFL) and Bloomberg Trading Facility B.V. (BV), two foreign-based firms that operate multilateral trading facilities for fixed income securities and swaps. The settlement follows allegations by OSC Staff that the firms operated marketplaces without authorization in Ontario, filed applications for exemptive relief with the Commission containing incomplete and inaccurate information and, in the case of BTFL, failed to comply with terms and conditions set out in an exemptive relief order. As part of the settlement agreement, BTFL and BV have paid an administrative penalty of CAD $2,506,011.80 and disgorged $663,305.20.
source_url: https://www.osc.ca/en/news-events/news/osc-panel-approves-settlement-bloomberg-trading-facility-limited-and-bloomberg-trading-facility-bv

summary: Aviscar Inc. and Budgetcar Inc. / Budgetauto Inc. agreed to pay a C$3 million administrative monetary penalty for what the Bureau concluded was false or misleading advertising for prices and discounts on car rentals and associated products. They also agreed to pay $250,000 towards the Bureau's investigative costs and will be required to implement a corporate compliance program.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2016/06/avis-and-budget-to-ensure-prices-advertised-are-accurate.html

summary: The Competition Bureau announced that Solvay Chemicals Inc. had been fined C$2.5 million by the Federal Court after the company pleaded guilty to criminal charges for fixing the price of hydrogen peroxide sold in Canada.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200220213356/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03228.html

summary: The Competition Bureau announced that Cargolux Airlines International S.A. pleaded guilty in Federal Court and was fined C$2.5 million for its role in an air cargo cartel affecting Canada.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200220210154/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03304.html

summary: A Bureau investigation concluded that, outside the province of Quebec, Sirius advertised their satellite radio and streaming subscription plans at prices that are not attainable due to an additional mandatory fee, a practice known as drip pricing.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2024/06/sirius-to-pay-33-million-penalty-to-settle-concerns-over-subscription-price-advertising.html

summary: FCAC Staff alleged that the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CIBC) had violated the Cost of Borrowing (Banks) Regulations, as it applied at the time of the violation, by not transferring some transactions to the new credit card statement once a lost, stolen or defrauded credit card had been deactivated. The Commissioner agreed that the violation had occurred and imposed a penalty of C$3 million.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/financial-consumer-agency/services/industry/commissioner-decisions/decision-144.html

summary: DENSO Corporation, a Japanese supplier of motor vehicle components, pleaded guilty to three counts of bid-rigging under the Competition Act and was fined C$2.45 million by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice (East Region) for its participation in an international bid-rigging conspiracy.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200222130756/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03792.html

summary: Volkswagen Group Canada Inc. and Audi Canada Inc. agreed to pay C$2.5 million to resolve allegations that they misled consumers by promoting vehicles sold or leased in Canada as having clean 3.0 liter diesel engines with reduced emissions that were cleaner than an equivalent gasoline engine.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2018/01/up_to_290_5_millionincompensationforcanadiansinvolkswagenaudiand.html

summary: On June 15, 2017, Canadian National Railway Company (CN) pleaded guilty, in the Provincial Court of Alberta, to one offence under the Fisheries Act and three offences under the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999. As a result, CN has been ordered to pay $2,500,000, which will be directed to the Environmental Damages Fund.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/environmental-enforcement/notifications/national-railway-company-environmental-offences.html

summary: On April 26, 2024, in the Provincial Court of Newfoundland and Labrador, Husky Oil Operations Limited was ordered to pay C$2 million after earlier pleading guilty to one charge under the federal Fisheries Act and one charge under the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994. The company was also ordered to pay $500,000 for an offence under the Canada-Newfoundland and Labrador Atlantic Accord Implementation Act that was investigated by conservation officers with the Canada-Newfoundland and Labrador Offshore Petroleum Board. The charges relate to a crude oil release on November 16, 2018, at the White Rose oil field in the Newfoundland and Labrador offshore area, where an estimated 250,000 litres of crude oil were released into the environment due to a failure of the subsea flowline connector from the SeaRose Floating Production, Storage and Offloading installation.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/environmental-enforcement/notifications/husky-oil-operations-limited-fined-three-offences-federal-legislation-crude-oil-release-newfoundland-labrador-offshore.html

enforcing_agency: Canada-Newfoundland and Labrador Offshore Petroleum Board
summary: Husky Oil Operations Limited, currently known as Cenovus Energy Inc., was sentenced to a total of $2.5 million after pleading guilty to a charge related to a 2018 spill of petroleum.
source_url: https://www.cnlopb.ca/news/husky-oil-operations-limited-fined-as-a-result-of-november-2018-spill-in-the-white-rose-field/

summary: Royal Bank of Canada was fined C$2.2 million for failing to adequately discharge mortgages-- the process a bank must go through to relinquish its right to seize a property once a mortgage has been paid off in full.
source_url: https://www.consumerprotectionbc.ca/recent-enforcement-actions-details/?cpbc_caseNumber=31446

summary: Two workers were fatally injured when a tank roof support structure collapsed at the west tank farm at the CNRL Horizon site. Two Sinopec Shanghai Engineering Company (SSEC) Canada Ltd. workers were seriously injured and three SSEC Canada Ltd. workers received minor injuries. On September 5, 2012 the company pled guilty to three charges under Section 2(1)(a)(i) of the Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) Act, for failing to ensure, as far as reasonably practicable, the health and safety of a worker engaged in the work of that employer. The company was sentenced to a C$1.5 million penalty including a C$200,000 fine and a C$1.3 million payment to the Alberta Law Foundation to be used to support an outreach and education program, to be developed by the Alberta Workers Health Centre, the Edmonton Multicultural Health Brokers and the Calgary Workers Resource Centre.
source_url: https://www.alberta.ca/convictions-under-ohs-legislation

summary: RBC is alleged to have failed to keep such books and records and remediate identified non-compliance with its internal accounting policies as were necessary to properly record the financial affairs of RBC as they relate to the capitalization of internally developed software. The deficiencies noted by the AMF, although not material to RBC financial disclosures, nevertheless impugned the integrity of Quebec's capital markets and RBC's conduct was therefore contrary to the public interest. RBC agreed to make a voluntary payment in the amount of C$2,000,000 pursuant to the agreement reached with the AMF.

summary: The consent agreement was the result of an investigation in which the Bureau concluded that Hertz and Dollar Thrifty were advertising enticing low prices to attract consumers. However, those low prices were unattainable because mandatory fees were systematically added. The Bureau concluded that the companies' price representations were misleading, and it was not sufficient for the companies to provide an estimate of the total price before consumers completed their reservation.

The charges relate to the failure to notify authorities of a deposit of a deleterious substance into the Red Deer River, which is fish-bearing.

summary: Enbridge Gas Distribution Inc., of North York, was fined C$350,000 for a violation of the Occupational Health and Safety Act after an explosion near a construction site. In addition, Enbridge pleaded guilty to charges under sec. 9(2) of Ontario Regulation 210/91 under the Technical Standards and Safety Act, 2000 and was fined an additional C$350,000.
source_url: https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/19827/gas-company-utility-locator-and-excavator-fined-in-excess-of-11-million-total-after-explosion

summary: WorkSafeBC attended this firm's smelter worksite in response to an incident. A worker was on an elevated work platform, conducting maintenance on an overhead travelling crane. After repairs were complete, the crane was tested. While the crane was moving, it contacted the platform and caused it to tip over while the worker was still on it, and the worker was injured. WorkSafeBC determined there were no safe work procedures for this type of maintenance work. In addition, the firm had put the crane back into use after the incident before it had been certified as safe. The firm failed to ensure that, if it was not practicable to shut down machinery for maintenance, only the parts vital to the process remained energized, and that the work was performed by workers who have been provided with and follow written safe work procedures. This was a high-risk violation. The firm also failed to ensure its crane subject to misadventure was removed from service until an engineer inspected it and certified it as safe for use, a repeated violation.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

company_name: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Canada)
enforcing_agency: Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada-FINTRAC
summary: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Canada), also operating as ICBC (Canada), ICBK (Canada) and ICBK, was fined C$701,250 for committing three violations of anti-money-laundering regulations.
source_url: https://fintrac-canafe.canada.ca/pen/amps/pen-2021-12-23-eng

summary: WorkSafeBC inspected a building used for cleaning and servicing of equipment at this firm's aluminum smelter. The inspection was to follow up on a recommendation the joint occupational health and safety committee submitted to the employer related to controlling workers' exposure to process dust that contained toxic substances (including beryllium). WorkSafeBC had issued previous orders to this firm regarding control of harmful airborne dust and accumulations. WorkSafeBC determined that the firm's work procedures for siphon cleaning included the use of air pressure, which created a significant amount of process dust with no means to capture the dust. The control measures in place did not include more effective engineering or administrative controls as required. The firm failed to implement an exposure control plan to maintain workers' exposure as low as reasonably achievable. This was a repeated and high-risk violation.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: WorkSafeBC inspected this employer's powerhouse for a hydroelectric dam construction. WorkSafeBC observed damaged ventilation equipment and deficiencies with the employer's practices to address welding fume hazards. In addition, the subcontracted firm conducting the welding work did not have an adequate exposure control plan in place for welding fumes. As prime contractor of a multiple-employer workplace, the employer failed to establish and maintain a system of regulatory compliance, a high-risk violation. The employer also failed to keep up-to-date written procedures for providing first aid at the worksite. These were both repeated violations.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: The Competition Bureau announced that Suncor Energy Products Inc. pleaded guilty to fixing the price of retail gasoline from May to November 2007 in Belleville, Ontario. The Ontario Superior Court sentenced it to pay a fine of C$500,000.
source_url: https://web.archive.org/web/20200207195724/https://www.competitionbureau.gc.ca/eic/site/cb-bc.nsf/eng/03460.html

summary: WorkSafeBC responded to two incidents at this firm's smelter worksite. In the first incident, a subcontracted worker received an electrical shock injury from an energized conductor on an electrical power distribution system. In the second incident, a subcontracted worker was injured when they made contact with a rotary valve on a dust collector.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: WorkSafeBC investigated an incident at this firm's cement manufacturing facility. When a large fan at the site failed, debris broke through the fan housing and struck a nearby worker. The worker sustained fatal injuries. WorkSafeBC's investigation determined that the fan's impeller had been repaired and refurbished about five months prior to the incident. The firm failed to ensure the installation, inspection, testing, and repair of its equipment was done as specified by the manufacturer or a professional engineer. The firm also failed to ensure that, if equipment was dismantled and subsequently re-assembled, it was checked by a qualified person and determined to be safe before operation. In addition, the firm failed to ensure the health and safety of all workers at its workplace, and failed to provide workers with the information, instruction, training, and supervision necessary to ensure their health and safety. These were all high-risk violations.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: WorkSafeBC inspected this firm's zinc production facility. During the inspection, a worker was observed walking through an energized equipment area to operate a control panel. No barrier or other safeguard was in place as required to prevent worker access through this hazardous area. The firm failed to ensure equipment was fitted with adequate safeguards to ensure workers could not access hazardous points of operation. This was a repeated and high-risk violation.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: The National Bank of Canada was fined C$600,000 for two alleged violations of the Cost of Borrowing (Banks) Regulations, as it applied at the time of the violations. Customers were being charged fees for personal loans that were different than those identified initially in the documentation because the system was not processing interest payments on non-business days.

summary: Japanese car parts manufacturer NGK Spark Plug Co., Ltd. pleaded guilty to one count of bid-rigging for participating in an international conspiracy and was fined C$550,000 by the Ontario Superior Court of Justice.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2017/12/ngk_to_pay_550_000forriggingbidsforcarparts.html

summary: This firm's worksite was a hydroelectric dam under construction. WorkSafeBC inspected the site in response to an incident where a worker was injured after falling about 12.2 m (40 ft.) from a formwork shoring deck. Holes had been cut out in the deck to accommodate the installation of future shoring tower components. The worker, who was wearing a fall protection harness but was not connected to a lifeline, had been walking on the deck and fell through one of the holes. WorkSafeBC observed that the hole the worker fell through was one of multiple uncovered, unguarded openings in shoring decks within the work zone. WorkSafeBC also observed a ladder that workers used to access work areas that placed them above erected guardrail sections. In addition, WorkSafeBC determined the firm's fall protection plan had only been verbally communicated to workers and did not include specific instructions on what fall protection system to use while accessing work areas. There was also no evidence that anyone in a supervisory role had checked on the workers to ensure the job task was being completed as planned. The firm failed to ensure fall protection was used, to have a written fall protection plan in place, and to ensure workers were instructed in the fall protection system to be used in their work area. The firm also failed to ensure floor openings were covered or guarded and identified, and to ensure there was a safe means of access and egress to each working level. Finally, the firm failed to provide its workers with the information, instruction, training, and supervision necessary to ensure their health and safety, a repeated violation. These were all high-risk violations.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: The FCAC alleged that the Bank of Montreal (BMO) committed two violations of the Negative Option Billing Regulations between 2014 and 2017 for failing to obtain and confirm consent for its credit card balance protection product. BMO paid the penalties, thereby admitting to the violations, but objected to having its name made public. The Commissioner determined that it would be appropriate to make public the name of the bank in this case.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/financial-consumer-agency/services/industry/commissioner-decisions/decision-138.html

summary: Syncrude Canada Ltd. entered a guilty plea to Section 189 of the Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) Code. All other charges were withdrawn upon acceptance of the guilty plea. Syncrude Canada Ltd. was fined C$10,000 plus a surcharge of C$1,500, and ordered to pay an additional C$365,000 pursuant to Section 41.1 of the Occupational Health and Safety Act, in favor of Keyano College for the development and implementation of a safety module for the Process Operators, Power Engineering and OHS programs respecting hazard assessments, awareness and control in relation to winter conditions and the formation of ice.
source_url: https://www.alberta.ca/convictions-under-ohs-legislation

summary: A worker was fatally injured while performing maintenance on a machine that was inadequately locked out. Resolute FP Canada Inc. failed to ensure that the machine was locked out as prescribed by section 76(a) of Ontario Regulation 851, contrary to section 25(1)(c) of the Occupational Health and Safety Act.
source_url: https://news.ontario.ca/en/court/1003994/lumber-producer-fined-500000-after-worker-fatally-injured

summary: An agreement was reached between the Autorite des marches financiers and Chubb Life Insurance Company of Canada under which an administrative penalty of C$450,000 was paid for non-compliance relating to the distribution of an insurance product, Sears Financial Guaranteed Issue Critical Illness Plan, which was offered to Sears credit card holders.

summary: A heavy equipment technician was conducting shovel maintenance duties when the worker was struck by a piece of equipment that was suspended from a crane and fell. The worker sustained fatal injuries. Suncor Energy Services pleaded guilty to OHS Code Sec. 296 for failure to ensure sharp edges on loads being hoisted were guarded to prevent damage to the rigging.
source_url: https://www.alberta.ca/convictions-under-ohs-legislation

summary: Two of this firm's workers, one of whom was a supervisor, attended a scene where two electrical cable faults had occurred in a manhole. One of the workers entered the manhole, a confined space, to visually inspect the damaged circuits. WorkSafeBC's investigation determined that the firm's confined space program did not include written safe work procedures addressing entry into a confined space after an electrical fault, and that the hazard assessment of the confined space failed to consider conditions existing prior to entry, both repeated violations. The hazard assessment also failed to adequately address the atmospheric hazards in the confined space, and the written procedures developed failed to specify the means to eliminate or minimize the hazards likely to occur. The firm's failure to ensure the hazard assessment and written confined space entry procedures were prepared by a qualified person was a repeated violation. Further, the firm failed to provide its workers with the information, instruction, training, and supervision necessary to ensure their health and safety. These were all high-risk violations.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: Japanese shipping companies Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) and Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, Ltd. (K Line) were respectively fined C$1.5 million and C$460,000 by the Ontario Superior Court for their role in an international conspiracy that reduced competition for the shipment of vehicles to Canada.

summary: An agreement was reached between the Autorite des marches financiers and the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company under which an administrative penalty of C$350,000 was paid for non-compliance related to the distribution of a hospitalization insurance product called Regime hospitalisation Sears. This product was being sold to Sears credit card holders.
source_url: https://lautorite.qc.ca/en/general-public/media-centre/news/fiche-dactualites/agreement-between-amf-and-the-manufacturers-life-insurance-company-1

summary: WorkSafeBC inspected three of this firm's worksites. At the first worksite, an underground gas line had been struck by an excavator. WorkSafeBC's investigation determined the excavation work had not been done according to regulatory requirements, and that workers had entered an unsafe excavation. At the second worksite, WorkSafeBC observed work being done with a corrosive inhibitor without a current safety data sheet (SDS) on site or appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) for workers. At the third site, demolition work was being done that involved lead paint, but the paint had not been sampled as part of the hazardous materials survey and there was no exposure control plan in place. The firm failed to ensure excavation work was done in accordance with the written instructions of a qualified professional. The firm also failed to have an up-to-date supplier SDS for hazardous materials in use on site, and to ensure a qualified person collected representative samples of hazardous materials. In addition, as prime contractor at a multiple-employer worksite, the firm failed to do everything reasonable to establish and maintain a system of regulatory compliance, a repeated violation.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: The FCAC alleged that the Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) committed one violation of the Credit Business Practices (Banks, Authorized Foreign Banks, Trust and Loan Companies, Retail Associations, Canadian Insurance Companies and Foreign Insurance Companies) Regulations between 2015 and 2017 for failing to obtain consent from customers before applying pre-approved credit card limit increases. The Commissioner found that RBC had committed this violation as alleged, and imposed a penalty of C$350,000.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/financial-consumer-agency/services/industry/commissioner-decisions/decision-139.html

summary: On July 25, 2022, De Beers Canada, Inc. was sentenced to pay $350,000, in Yellowknife Territorial Court, Northwest Territories, after pleading guilty to one offence under the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 (CEPA), in violation of the Storage Tank Systems for Petroleum Products and Allied Petroleum Products Regulations, subsection 2.1(1). The fine will be directed to the Government of Canada's Environmental Damages Fund to support projects that benefit the natural environment.
source_url: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/environmental-enforcement/notifications/diesel-spill-northwest-territories-diamond-mine-fine.html

summary: WorkSafeBC inspected this firm's worksite and observed workers inside a large container used to process materials during cement manufacturing. The workers were applying a lining to the interior wall of the container, which was a confined space. WorkSafeBC determined that the firm's work procedures had not been developed to address the specific hazards of the refractory, scaffolding, and mechanical work being done inside this space. The firm failed to conduct an adequate confined space hazard assessment, and failed to develop written procedures to eliminate or minimize hazards. These were both repeated violations.
source_url: https://www.worksafebc.com/en/health-safety/create-manage/incident-investigations/penalties/penalty-summaries

summary: A heavy equipment technician was conducting shovel maintenance duties when the worker was struck by a piece of equipment that was suspended from a crane and fell. Joy Global (Canada) pleaded guilty to OHS Act Sec. 3(1)(a)(i) for failure to ensure the health and safety of its worker, by failing to ensure the worker was trained to select suitable softeners for use with synthetic slings.
